Introduction

Idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis (IPF) is an interstitial lung disease (ILD) characterized by progressive fibrotic changes in the lung parenchyma leading to respiratory function decline, morbidity, and mortality.  IPF affects roughly 1 in 4,000 adults worldwide.  By definition, IPF lacks a definite underlying cause, although recent advances suggest genetic and environmental contributing factors.

Pathogenesis

Pathophysiology



IPF is an aberrant wound-healing response to repetitive alveolar epithelial injury.  Instead of normal restoration, the alveolar surface is replaced via fibrosis.  Key steps in pathogenesis include:



  • Epithelial injury:  IPF likely begins with an initial insult to the alveolar epithelium (eg, due to smoking, acid reflux, recurrent aspiration, or viral infections).  Type I pneumocytes, the squamous epithelial cells that cover 90% of the alveolar surface, are damaged and depleted.
  • Cellular senescence:  Normally, damaged type I pneumocytes are replaced through differentiation of type II pneumocytes, the alveolar progenitor cells that also secrete pulmonary surfactant.  In individuals with IPF, type II pneumocytes undergo accelerated senescence that exhausts their regenerative potential.  Contributing factors include telomere shorting (eg, telomerase mutations) and cellular stress (eg, surfactant protein mutations).
  • Fibroblast activation:  When type I pneumocytes are depleted, the resulting epithelial defect triggers profibrotic pathways such as those involving transforming growth factor beta (TGFÎ²), platelet-derived growth factor (PDGF), fibroblast growth factor (FGF), and Wnt/Î²-catenin.
  • Minimal inflammation:  A distinctive aspect of IPF is the lack of a significant immune or inflammatory response in the alveolar tissue.  However, alveolar macrophages likely play a role in driving fibrosis.

Risk factors



Risk factors for IPF represent gene-environment interactions that promote alveolar injury, senescence, and fibrosis.



  • Genetic factors:  Susceptibility alleles include genes involved in mucin defense (eg, MUC5B), telomere maintenance (eg, TERC, TERT), and surfactant production (eg, SFPC).  Loss-of-function polymorphisms in these loci are linked to familial pulmonary fibrosis.
  • Environmental factors:  Established risk factors include aging (eg, â‰¥60), smoking, acid reflux, frequent respiratory viral infections, and occupational exposures (eg, asbestos, metal fumes).


IPF is more common among males than females (2:1 ratio), likely reflecting historically higher rates of cigarette smoking in men.  Recent epidemiology shows that the sex gap is closing, similar to the trend observed for chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD).

Usual interstitial pneumonia



The hallmark of IPF is usual interstitial pneumonia (UIP), which has radiologic and histologic definitions:



  • Radiologic UIP (

    ), which is a pattern of fibrosis with:

    • Basilar (ie, lower-lobe) and peripheral (ie, subpleural) predominance.
    • Honeycombing (tiny cyst-like structures formed by fibrotic retraction of the airspaces).
  • Histologic UIP, which is a pattern of fibrosis characterized by minimal inflammation and heterogeneity in space and time:
    • Spatial heterogeneity:  Areas of fibrosis are interspersed with normal lung tissue.
    • Temporal heterogeneity:  Areas of fibrosis are at different stages of development within the same tissue sample, reflecting ongoing cycles of injury, repair, and scarring.  Early fibrosis is characterized by clusters of activated fibroblasts (fibroblastic foci) and loose collagen.  In contrast, late fibrosis is characterized by dense acellular collagen causing airspace retraction (microscopic honeycombing).


UIP can occur idiopathically (IPF) or secondary to a known cause (eg, drugs, autoimmune disorder).

Clinical presentation and diagnosis

Presentation



IPF presents insidiously with slowly progressive exertional dyspnea in older adults, typically in those with a history of smoking.  Patients are typically unsure when symptoms began, and many describe a remote respiratory infection they never fully recovered from.  A nagging, dry cough is also common.  Nonspecific symptoms (eg, fatigue, myalgias, arthralgias) and a general sense of being unwell are also reported.



Physical examination usually reveals fine, dry, Velcro-like, inspiratory crackles on lung auscultation.  The sound is formed as fibrotic alveolar walls snap open during inflation.  These crackles are a sensitive and early sign, often audible years before radiographic fibrosis can be visualized.  As IPF progresses, signs of chronic hypoxemia, such as cyanosis and digital clubbing, can be seen.  Pulmonary hypertension and right ventricular failure (eg, elevated jugular venous pressure, edema) often develop as complications of advanced disease.



Because IPF can be diagnosed only if secondary causes are excluded, the following pertinent negatives are important:



  • No pneumotoxic drug exposure (eg, nitrofurantoin, amiodarone, methotrexate, bleomycin).
  • No major exposure to dust, fibers, organic antigens, or radiation.
  • No signs of an underlying autoimmune condition (eg, Raynaud syndrome, telangiectasias, synovitis, photodermatitis).

Studies



Chest x-ray is insensitive but may show volume loss (ie, decreased expansion) and diffuse reticular (lacy) thickening, particularly in the lower lobes and periphery.  The gold standard for diagnosis is high-resolution CT (HRCT), which provides thin imaging cuts (~1 mm vs 5 mm in conventional CT) for better visualization of the parenchyma.  This confirms the basilar (lower lobe) and peripheral (subpleural) distribution (

image 1
) and shows honeycombing (
image 2
), which is the definitive feature of UIP.  In advanced stages, widespread fibrosis pulls the lung tissue inward, which leads to traction bronchiectasis and other architectural distortions (
image 3
).



Pulmonary function testing reveals a restrictive pattern (

figure 1
) on spirometry: forced vital capacity (FVC) and forced expiratory volume in 1 second (FEV1) are reduced, but FEV1/FVC ratio is normal (â‰¥0.7).  In fact, FEV1/FVC is often elevated because fibrosis produces abnormally high elastic recoil.  Lung volumes are decreased (eg, total lung capacity <80% predicted).  Diffusion capacity is reduced due to interstitial thickening (eg, diffusing capacity of the lungs for carbon monoxide [DLCO] <80% predicted).  The flow volume loop is narrowed and steep (
figure 2
).



Autoimmune serologies (eg, antinuclear antibody, rheumatoid factor) are usually obtained to assess for an underlying rheumatic or connective tissue disorder (

ðŸ“Š View Table: table 2
).  In IPF, autoimmune titers are either negative or weakly/nonspecifically positive.

Diagnosis



By definition, IPF is radiologic or histologic UIP with no secondary cause.



Diagnosis of IPF is made based on clinical, radiologic, and (sometimes) histologic criteria.  The key decision point is whether a biopsy is required.



Biopsy is not required in most cases.  IPF can be diagnosed via clinical and radiologic criteria when all of the following criteria are met:



  • Older patient (age â‰¥60).
  • HRCT with classic radiographic UIP (ie, basilar subpleural honeycombing).
  • No evidence of an autoimmune disease or environmental exposure.


Meeting all of the above criteria has >97% specificity for IPF; biopsy reveals an alternative diagnosis in <3% of cases and is therefore unnecessary.  If biopsy is obtained, histology shows patchy subpleural fibrosis, temporal heterogeneity (eg, areas with more mature collagen than others), and microscopic honeycombing (eg, dilated airspaces due to fibrotic traction).



Biopsy may be needed if any one of the following criteria are met:



  • Younger patient (unless part of familial pulmonary fibrosis cluster).
  • HRCT with features inconsistent with UIP (eg, ground-glass opacities, mid- or upper-lobe predominance, nodules, or consolidations).
  • Possible underlying autoimmune disease (eg, positive serology with evidence of rheumatism) or environmental exposure (eg, domestic birds, moldy soil).


In these cases, the goal of biopsy is to exclude inflammatory or environmental ILD such as hypersensitivity pneumonitis (HP), pulmonary sarcoidosis, or autoimmune-associated interstitial pneumonias.  These conditions are treated very differently than IPF (eg, immunosuppression vs antifibrotic drugs).



Diagnosis of IPF is ideally made via multidisciplinary case review with input from pulmonary, rheumatologic, radiologic, and pathologic specialists.  Multidisciplinary review at an established referral center increases the accuracy of diagnosis from 50% to 90%.

Differential diagnosis

Other cardiopulmonary conditions



The classic presentation of IPF is in an older patient with chronic dyspnea, fatigue, and a significant smoking history.  Other conditions on the differential include:



  • COPD:  Patients have an obstructive pattern (ie, FEV1/FVC <0.7) on spirometry (vs a restrictive pattern in IPF), barrel chest and hyperinflation (vs low lung volumes in IPF), and diminished breath sounds or expiratory wheezing (vs inspiratory crackles in IPF).
  • Ischemic heart disease:  Exertional dyspnea can sometimes be the primary manifestation of ischemia (eg, anginal equivalent) instead of chest pain.  In coronary disease, the dyspnea tends to recover rapidly with rest and is not associated with hypoxemia.  In contrast, IPF-related dyspnea resolves more slowly and is associated with measurable desaturation.
  • Lung cancer:  Dyspnea usually indicates advanced lung cancer (eg, large mass causing bronchial obstruction).  Patients usually have a more focal lung exam (vs symmetric with IPF) and a productive or bloody cough (vs dry cough with IPF).


Importantly, these conditions are often comorbid with IPF (discussed below).

Non-UIP interstitial lung diseases



Other ILDs include (

ðŸ“Š View Table: table 3
):



  • Chronic HP:  Chronic HP is an immunologic response to inhaled organic antigens (eg, bird dander, molds) that causes granulomatous inflammation and eventual fibrosis.  HP lacks honeycombing and primarily affects the middle and upper lobes (vs lower lobes in IPF).
  • Fibrotic pulmonary sarcoidosis:  Although most patients exhibit bihilar adenopathy and perilymphatic granulomas that wax and wane over time, irreversible parenchymal fibrosis develops in approximately 10% of patients with sarcoidosis.  Sarcoidosis lacks honeycombing and primarily affects the middle and upper lobes (vs lower lobes in IPF).  Most patients have extrapulmonary manifestations (eg, ocular disease, hypercalcemia), which are absent in IPF.
  • Silicosis:  Progressive massive fibrosis is a severe form of chronic silicosis characterized by large confluent fibrotic masses in the upper lobes.  Patients usually also have smaller widespread silicotic nodules and calcified hilar lymph nodes.
  • Other idiopathic interstitial pneumonias (IIPs):  The IIPs include IPF and other ILDs (for reference, not memorization): nonspecific interstitial pneumonia (NSIP), cryptogenic organizing pneumonia (COP), lymphocytic interstitial pneumonia (LIP), desquamative interstitial pneumonia (DIP), respiratory bronchiolitisâ€“ILD (RB-ILD), and acute interstitial pneumonia (AIP).  In contrast to UIP, these IIPs are characterized by inflammatory changes (eg, ground-glass or consolidative opacities) rather than honeycombing fibrosis.  A conceptual overview of ILDs is presented in a separate article.

Nonspecific pulmonary scarring



The term "pulmonary fibrosis" appears commonly in radiograph reports.  However, it most often represents secondary fibrosis in response to infection (eg, pneumonia) or inflammation (eg, aspiration), rather than IPF (which is uncommon).  Features that help differentiate these forms of secondary fibrosis from ILD include localization (eg, at site of prior pneumonia), specific radiographic features (eg, amorphous, no honeycombing), and stability over time.

Other causes of UIP



As discussed above, a UIP pattern of fibrosis is the hallmark of IPF, but other (secondary) causes must be excluded.  These include:



  • Autoimmune-associated UIP:  Several autoimmune conditions can induce various ILDs, such as organizing pneumonia, NSIP, and UIP.  Rheumatoid arthritis, systemic sclerosis, and polymyositis/dermatomyositis are most closely associated with UIP (although other patterns are still more common).
  • Drug-induced UIP:  Many drugs can induce pulmonary toxicity, such as eosinophilic pneumonitis, organizing pneumonia, and UIP.  Busulfan, bleomycin, nitrofurantoin, methotrexate, and amiodarone are the most closely associated with UIP (although other patterns are still more common).
  • Asbestos-induced UIP:  Asbestosis produces a pattern of fibrosis that is very similar to UIP (eg, basilar honeycombing).  However, it can be distinguished by calcified plaques on the pleura, chest wall, and diaphragm.

Management

Treatment



The goal of IPF treatment is to slow the rate of lung function decline and improve quality of life.  Other than lung transplant for end-stage disease, no intervention can restore lung function after it is lost.



  • Antifibrotic therapy:  Two approved antifibrotic drugs, pirfenidone and nintedanib, inhibit fibroblast activation and collagen synthesis by blocking receptors for TGFÎ², FGF, and PDGF.  They slow the rate of FVC decline by approximately 200 mL/year, decrease the risk for acute exacerbations of IPF, and likely improve survival.  Ideally, antifibrotics are initiated at earlier stages of disease (eg, FVC 50%-80%) to maximally preserve lung function.  Major adverse effects include gastrointestinal distress and fatigue, which are often so severe they are perceived as worse than the symptoms of IPF itself.
  • Avoidance of immunosuppression:  IPF lacks active inflammatory or immunologic lung injury.  Use of immunosuppressive drugs is associated with increased infection risk and mortality.

Supportive care



As in other chronic pulmonary diseases, patients benefit from:



  • Smoking cessation.
  • Long-term oxygen therapy, targeting SaO2 â‰¥88% to prevent cor pulmonale.
  • Pulmonary rehabilitation, including supervised exercise, nutritional support (eg, for pulmonary cachexia), education (eg, proper use of oxygen), and psychosocial assessment.
  • Immunizations against Streptococcus pneumoniae, influenza, respiratory syncytial virus, and SARS-CoV-2.

Comorbidities



Patients with IPF usually have multiple other chronic cardiopulmonary conditions (eg, with age and smoking as common risk factors):



  • Gastroesophageal reflux disease warrants treatment with antacid therapy (eg, proton pump inhibitor) to prevent further cycles of alveolar injury from aspiration.
  • COPD can coexist with IPF and is treated with long-acting bronchodilators.
  • Sleep disordered breathing, such as obstructive sleep apnea, is common, and is treated with nocturnal positive airway pressure.  All patients with significant chronic lung disease, such as IPF and COPD, should be screened for nocturnal hypoxemia and symptoms of sleep apnea.
  • Coronary artery disease and left heart failure (especially diastolic dysfunction) can present with exertional dyspnea.  Patients with dyspnea disproportionate to their lung function or imaging findings should be assessed for cardiogenic cause (eg, with perfusion stress testing or echocardiography).
  • Lung cancer risk is elevated (even above that of smokers without IPF), and selected patients may benefit from routine CT screening if consistent with goals of care.

Acute exacerbations of IPF



Acute exacerbation of IPF (AE-IPF) is a life-threatening complication with the following features:



  • Rapid worsening of respiratory status (ie, <1 month).
  • Chest imaging with new widespread acute alveolar damage (eg, ground-glass opacities) superimposed on prior UIP.
  • Unexplained by fluid overload or left ventricular failure.


AE-IPF can be provoked by an acute insult (eg, aspiration, infection, procedural trauma), but often there is no trigger identified.  Diagnosis is based on clinical symptoms and imaging.  Respiratory viral panel and bronchoalveolar lavage are usually performed to exclude infection.  Invasive lung biopsy is avoided because it aggravates lung injury and is associated with higher mortality.



Patients are usually very ill (eg, requiring hospitalization).  Management involves high-dose systemic corticosteroids; empiric, broad-spectrum antibiotics; and supportive oxygenation (eg, high-flow nasal cannula).  Defining the goals of care is essential because the prognosis is grave (eg, median survival is 3 months).  Invasive mechanical ventilation should be avoided if possible due to medical futility.  Selected patients may be urgently listed for lung transplantation and may need to be bridged with extracorporeal membrane oxygenation (ECMO) due to severe hypoxemia.

Transplantation



Lung transplantation is the only definitive cure for IPF.  A distinction is made between transplant referral and listing:



  • Referral:  Referral connects the patient to a transplant program that can monitor disease progression, address eligibility barriers, and coordinate pretransplant work-up (eg, malignancy screening).  Of all chronic lung diseases, IPF has the highest waiting list mortality.  Therefore, early referral is appropriate for any degree of impairment (eg, FVC <80%, any dyspnea, any hypoxemia).  Response to antifibrotic therapy has no bearing on this decision.  This proactive approach is associated with improved survival, even in those not ultimately listed for transplant.
  • Listing:  Indications for active listing (for context, not memorization) include:
    • Accelerated lung function decline (eg, FVC or DLCO decreasing by >10% in 6 months).
    • Accelerated functional impairment (eg, 6-minute walk test decreasing by 50 meters in 6 months).
    • Pulmonary hypertension (cor pulmonale).
    • Hospitalization for respiratory failure, AE-IPF, or spontaneous pneumothorax (very unlikely to resolve due to fibrotic retraction of the lung).


These listing factors identify patients at highest risk for short-term mortality.

Prognosis



Prognosis of IPF remains poor, with a median survival of 3-5 years from diagnosis.  There is wide variation.  Around 25% of patients have a nonprogressive phenotype and routinely live for over 10 years after diagnosis.  However, most patients have progressive fibrosis and poorer outcomes.  On average, FVC declines by approximately 400 mL per year without antifibrotic therapy.  (The right middle lobe has roughly the same volume, meaning that living with untreated IPF is equivalent to undergoing a lobectomy every year.)



Due to the progressive, incurable nature of IPF, goals of care (eg, do-not-resuscitate order status, life-sustaining treatment) should be discussed.  Patients should be counseled that prolonged mechanical ventilation is medically futile and typically leads to greater harm (eg, barotrauma from trying to inflate stiff lungs).  Regardless of disease stage, palliative care (eg, low-dose opioids for dyspnea, psychosocial support) should be offered to all patients with significant symptoms impacting their quality of life.  It is usually integrated alongside standard medical care (

figure 3
).

Summary



Idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis (IPF) (

ðŸ“Š View Table: table 4
) is an interstitial lung disease marked by fibrosis of the lung parenchyma leading to progressive loss of lung capacity, significant morbidity, and high mortality.  IPF arises from repeated alveolar injury that is repaired via fibrotic pathways instead of normal epithelial regeneration.  Risk factors include aging, genetic predisposition (eg, mutations in telomerase), and environmental exposures (eg, smoking, acid reflux, occupational dusts and fibers).  Clinically, IPF presents with insidious onset of exertional dyspnea, dry cough, and Velcro-like inspiratory crackles.  The hallmark of IPF is usual interstitial pneumonia (UIP), a distinctive pattern of fibrosis with minimal inflammation that is predominantly basilar and subpleural on radiology and that displays spatial and temporal heterogeneity on histology.  Honeycombing is unique to UIP and not seen in other interstitial lung diseases frequently on the differential diagnosis (eg, postinfectious fibrosis, hypersensitivity pneumonitis, sarcoidosis, idiopathic interstitial pneumonias).  Diagnosis can be made without biopsy in patients with high resolution CT scan showing classic UIP and no other explanation (eg, no occupational exposure or autoimmune disease).  Treatment focuses on slowing lung function decline with antifibrotic drugs, providing supportive care, and evaluating for a potential lung transplantation.
